title.value: Processing of social and monetary rewards in autism spectrum disorders
title.justification: The best literal quote indicating this is the title itself as found in the paper
title.quote: Processing of social and monetary rewards in autism spectrum disorders

extractions.description: This paper investigates the reward processing mechanisms in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) compared to typically developing participants. It specifically focuses on reward type (social, monetary) and reward phase (anticipation, delivery), utilising functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

type.justification: The paper involves the collection and analysis of fMRI data to assess brain activity related to reward processing.
type.quote: Functional magnetic resonance imaging during social and monetary reward anticipation and delivery was performed in 212 individuals with ASD (7.6–30.6 years of age) and 181 typically developing participants (7.6–30.8 years of age).

name.justification: The study focuses on brain activity related to reward processing, which falls under the domain of neuroscience.
name.quote: Reward processing has been proposed to underpin the atypical social feature of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

name.justification: The study involves a psychiatric condition, namely autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and its neurological underpinnings during reward processing.
name.quote:
Background
Reward processing has been proposed to underpin the atypical social feature of autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

name.justification: The study employs functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate brain activity.
name.quote: Functional magnetic resonance imaging during social and monetary reward anticipation and delivery was performed in 212 individuals with ASD (7.6–30.6 years of age) and 181 typically developing participants (7.6–30.8 years of age).

name.justification: The dataset used in this study is from the Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP), as indicated in the paper.
name.quote: The Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP17) provides a deeply phenotyped data-set of children, adolescents and adults with and without ASD who performed a social and a monetary reward task.

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): clinical characterisation
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper on the LEAP dataset is cited to show the dataset's comprehensive clinical characterisation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For further details about the study design we refer the reader to Loth et al,17 and for a comprehensive clinical characterisation of the LEAP cohort we refer the reader to Charman et al.19
